name: Language
note: Don't delete this file! It's used internally to help with page regeneration.
body:
### The Last of the Phoenicians
Many writing systems that we use today descended directly from the "abjad" alphabet created by Phoenicians in 1050 BC. Check out the letters => and how the Greeks copied them!
* alf ("ox") => alpha Αα (1) ...represented a glottal stop ("ʔ" in dene)
* bet ("house") => beta Ββ (2)
* gaml ("camel") => gamma Γγ (3) - g
* delt ("door") => delta "Δδ(4)"
* he ("window") => epsilon "Εε(5)"
* wau ("hook") => upsilon "Υυ(400)"
* zai ("weapon") => zeta "Ζζ(7)"
* het ("wall") => eta "Ηη(8)"
* tet ("wheel") => theta "Θθ(9)"
* yod ("hand") => iota "Ιι(10)"
* kaf ("palm") => kappa "Κκ(20)"
* lamd ("goad") => lambda "Λλ(30)"
* mem ("water") => mu "Μμ(40)"
* nun ("serpent") => nu "Νν(50)"
* semk ("fish") => xi "Ξξ(60)", chi "Χχ(600)"
* ain ("eye") => omicron "Οο(70)", omega "Ωω(800)"
* pe ("mouth") => pi "Ππ(80)"
* sade ("hunt") => san "Ϻϻ"
* qof ("needle head") => koppa "Ϙϙϟ(90)", phi "Φφ(500)", psi "Ψψ(700)"
* rosh ("head") => rho "Ρρ(100)"
* shin ("tooth") => sigma "Σσς(200)"
* tau ("mark") => tau "Ττ(300)"

Numbers
* one 1
* ten 10
* twenty 20
* one-hundred 100
* two 2
* three 3

Other info:
* Phnx, 115 (ISO 15924, Codes for the representation of names of scripts)
* phn (ISO 639-2, 639-2)
* http://www.unicode.org/charts/PDF/U10900.pdf
* Unicode Range 10900-1091F 
* Numbers: one, ten, twenty, one-hundred, two, three
* Punctuation: word-separator

![Phoenix "Coyotes"](http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/10/PHXold.svg/200px-PHXold.svg.png)

### Support or Contact
If you are having difficulty with Unicode in your computer programs, contact language@dene.ca and we’ll help you sort it out.
